channel.title: RSLoader
channel.description:
This is a nice simple loader derived from the work me and SilverLining did on Generibot. It's a multi-tabbed runescape loader, and that's about it xD
Features:
[ul][li]Multiple runescapes open at once, without using an unsigned client[/li] [li]Auto-updating, it checks for runescape updates at startup by querying the runescape servers[/li] [li]Plugginable interface for things such as combat calculators, etc.[/li][/ul]
Plans for the future:
[ul][li][s]A Plugginable interface for things such as combat calculators and other such rubbish[/s][/li] [li]More control from the config file[/li] [li][s]Clean the source![/s][/li][/ul]
So yeah, this is my first release in a while, feel free to post any criticisms as long as they're constructive.
PS: Forgot to mention, loader is modified so that it downloads runescape.jar and loads from that, this of course means that you can modify the runescape jar prior to loading; But I'd discourage that unless you know what you're doing.
[b]UPDATE:[/b] Updated to version 0.21, now includes plugginable interface, and some bugfixes.
[url=http://www.newbiehacker.net/RSLoader/release.zip][b][size=15pt]DOWNLOAD HERE [size=1](source included)[/size][/size][/b][/url]

item.title: RSLoader
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

because readFully will only read as many bytes as your buffer can hold, but the data might be longer than the buffer

ps: it is copied almost exactly from the loader

ByteArrayOutputStream bytearrayoutputstream = new ByteArrayOutputStream(); do { int i = zipinputstream.read(abyte1, 0, 1000); if(-1 == i) break; bytearrayoutputstream.write(abyte1, 0, i); } while(true); byte abyte2[] = bytearrayoutputstream.toByteArray();

Read full topic

item.title: RSLoader
item.dc:creator: @surfer25 surfer25
item.description:
@surfer25 wrote:

Just a quick question. I was looking at the source, and in com.rsloader.loader.CLoader, I noticed this:

byte[] buffer = new byte[5000];
                    ByteArrayOutputStream baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
                    int len;
                    InputStream is = jf.getInputStream(je);
                    while ((len = is.read(buffer)) != -1)
                        baos.write(buffer, 0, len);
                    is.close();
                    byte[] data = baos.toByteArray();
                    cache.put(cName, data);

And I’m wondering why you didn’t use java.io.DataInputStream land using the readFully method?

Read full topic
